cab.content: Printed for the War Cabinet. June 1944.W.P. (44) 300.7th June, 1944.WAR CABINET.PARLIAMENTARY SCRUTINY OF SUBORDINATE LEGISLATION.Memorandum by the Home Secretary.AT their Meeting on the 5th May the Cabinet agreed (W.M. (44)62nd Conclusions) that in the debate on Mr. Molson's Motion I should state thatthe Government were prepared to set up a Committee of the House of commons on the lines indicated in the memorandum circulated by the Chairman of theMachinery of Government Committee (W.P. (44) 223).In the debate on the 17th May I indicated the proposals which the Govern-ment were prepared to make, and these proposals were well received in all quarters of the House.Since the debate consideration has been given to the form of Motion whichwould be appropriate for the setting up of the proposed Select Committee forscrutinising subordinate legislation, and I have conferred thereon with theChancellor of the Exchequer as Chairman of the Machinery of government committee and with the Law Officers.As regards the terms of reference for the proposed Committee, furtherconsideration of the terms suggested in the memorandum W.P. (44) 223 has suggested that these terms might be improved in certain respects, with a view to bringing out more clearly the objects for which the Committee will be appointed and the extent of the Committee's responsibilities.I attach a draft of a Motion for the appointment of such Committee.Several of the Members who have especially interested themselves in thisquestion have asked that they may have an opportunity of conferring with mebefore the Motion is put down, and I propose to meet representative Membersof Parliament and indicate to them the scope and nature of the Government^proposals.Subject to any considerations which may emerge as the result of such consultation, I suggest that a Motion as in the draft attached be put down at anearly date.As to the size of the proposed Committee, it is in my view important thatif the Committee is to exercise its functions in a judicial spirit the number shouldbe kept as small as possible, and after consultation with the Chief Whip Iunderstand that it is proposed that the Committee should be limited to eleven.The Chief Whips will be in a position to inform the Cabinet of the proposedmembership when they consider this memorandum.H. M.Home Office, Whitehall, S.W.1,7th June, 1944.SECRET. - nCfbpy. No. di[27601] DRAFT.That a Select Committee be appointed to consider every Statutory orProvisional Rule or Order laid before the House or draft of such a Rule or order, being a Rule Order or draft upon which proceedings may be taken in either House in pursuance of any Act of Parliament, with a view to determining whether the special attention of the House should be drawn to it on any of thefollowing grounds: (i) that it imposes a charge on the public revenues or contains provisionsrequiring payments to be made to the Exchequer or any GovernmentDepartment or to any local or public authority in consideration ofany licence or consent, or of any services to be rendered, or prescribesthe amount of any such charge or payments :(ii) that it is made in pursuance of an enactment containing specificprovisions excluding it from challenge in the courts, either at all times or after the expiration of a specified period :(iii) that it appears to make some unusual or unexpected use of the powers conferred by the Statute under which it is made :(iv) that there appears to have been unjustifiable delay in the publicationof it:(v) that for any special reason, its form or purport calls for elucidation.That the Committee shall have power to require any Government Depart-ment concerned to submit a memorandum explaining any Rule Order or draft which may be under their consideration or to depute a representative to appearbefore them as a witness for the purpose of explaining any such Rule order or draft.That it be an Instruction to the Committee that before reporting that thespecial attention of the House should be drawn to any Rule Order or draft theCommittee shall afford to any Government Department concerned therewith anopportunity of furnishing orally or in writing such explanations as the depart-rnent thinks fit.
